title: 109_hr5892
content: The "Farmers Tax Deferral Act" allows for the nontaxable exchange of qualified agricultural property for real property under section 1046 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. No gain or loss recognized for qualified person receiving US real property in exchange for qualified agricultural property. Qualified person defined as individual age 55+, corporation owned by individuals age 55+, or partnership/trust/estate owned by individuals age 55+. Qualified agricultural property includes single purpose agricultural or horticultural property. Qualified agricultural property refers to specific agricultural or horticultural structures that have been in service for over 20 years and related real property, equipment, or fixtures. United States real property is defined as property located in the United States. Any property received in an exchange must be identified and completed within 180 days. Property received in an exchange is not considered real property if it is not identified within 45 days or received after 180 days from the transfer of the relinquished property. The transfer of the relinquished property occurs, and rules similar to section 1031 apply. A transaction described in this section is treated the same as a section 1031 transaction for tax purposes. Special rules apply for like-kind exchanges of qualified agricultural property. If qualified agricultural property is disposed of without recognizing gain under section 1046, the amount of gain considered by the transferor should not exceed the recognized gain on the disposition plus the fair market value of property acquired that is not section 1245 property. If qualified agricultural property is disposed of without recognizing gain under section 1046, the amount of gain considered by the transferor should not exceed the recognized gain on the disposition plus the fair market value of property acquired that is not section 1245 property. When United States real property acquired in an exchange to which section 1046 applies is disposed of by the transferee, the lesser of the excess of the amount realized on the disposition of such real property or the fair market value of the property is subject to ordinary income recapture. When qualified agricultural property is disposed of without recognizing gain under section 1046, the gain considered should not exceed the recognized gain on the disposition plus the fair market value of acquired property. If United States real property acquired in an exchange under section 1046 is sold, the excess of the amount realized or fair market value is subject to ordinary income recapture. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) of this Act apply to transfers and dispositions of qualified agricultural property after the enactment date. Special rules apply to installment sales of qualified agricultural property. Special rules apply to installment sales of qualified agricultural property under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Income from the installment sale is accounted for under the installment method, and recognized income for each taxable year is also recognized under this method. The amendments made by this section apply to sales after the enactment date.
